articleBody.value: Jalen Everett was acquitted Wednesday of the triple homicide on Genesee Street — the second time he has been tried for the crimes.
Everett's earlier second-degree murder conviction in the 2015 Genesee Street killings was tossed out by County Court Judge Douglas Randall after allegations of juror misconduct.
The jury took little time Wednesday finding him not guilty. It began deliberations in the morning and reached a verdict before 2 p.m.

A jury in November convicted Everett of second-degree murder, deciding he was involved in the 2015 drive-by shooting that left three dead in the Boys & Girls Club parking lot. However, after the verdict, a juror claimed that another juror had made racial comments and, during the trial, discussed information that the jury had not been allowed to hear.
Randall decided the claims of the juror were credible, and overturned the guilty verdict in December.

Everett was one of three men accused of the triple homicide outside the Boys & Girls Club, 500 Genesee St., on Aug. 19, 2015. One of the accused, Johnny Blackshell Jr., has been convicted of murder and sentenced to life in prison, while the other defendant, Michael Mathis, 19, will be tried separately.
Three young men — Jonah Barley, Raekwon Manigault and Johnny Johnson — died in the shooting. Three more were injured.
GCRAIG@Gannett.com

content.author: Sean Lahman, and Gary Craig, Democrat and Chronicle

articleBody.value: On Dec. 30, 2015, Emanuel Lutchman sat before a videocamera, a scarf wrapped around his face so that only his eyes showed, as he told the world of his planned New Year's Eve attack at a Rochester restaurant-bar.
"The blood that you spill of Muslims overseas we gonna spill the blood of the kuffar," Lutchman said, speaking of those who are non-believers or infidels, or the "kuffar."
Months before that video, Lutchman, after an argument with his girlfriend, stabbed himself in the stomach. A scar still remains.
These are the two pictures of Emanuel Lutchman, to be sentenced Thursday for aiding the terrorist organization, the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant, or ISIL.

To federal authorities, Lutchman is a ticking time bomb who, while serving a prison stint for robbery, grasped onto a radical Islamist theology that supplied a violent detour from the religion's more peaceful tenets. Thankfully, authorities say, he was arrested Dec. 30, 2015, and intercepted before he could kill.
In August, he pleaded guilty to aiding ISIL by planning the New Year's  Eve attack on patrons at Merchants Grill at 881 Merchants Road in Rochester.

To Lutchman's family and friends, he is a mentally troubled man incapable of pulling off a terrorist assault. They say his planned New Year's Eve crimes would have made no headway without the help of an FBI informant who bought Lutchman the machete he planned to use when he rushed into the bar.

"I am very sorry for what they are saying about him," his grandmotherBeverley Henry said in a pre-sentencing letter to the court. "With all his ups and down(s), he is not a bad person. He will not take a life."

The conundrum of Lutchman's personality goes to a bigger question for federal law enforcement: How do you differentiate a suspect who may truly be dangerous versus one who, while perhaps unhinged, is unlikely to carry out a terrorism-inspired crime?

"Who is the real threat?" said Peter Ahearn, who previously headed the western New York region's FBI office and now has a private security firm. "The system has checks and balances that are strictly enforced. Then the courts have the final determination in a lot of this."
Critics have claimed that the FBI maneuvered some unstable individuals into intricate planning of criminal acts.

"We have seen that there are times when it is clear, or should be clear, to law enforcement that someone doesn't pose a real threat," said Andrea Prasow, a deputy Washington director at Human Rights Watch, or HRW,  and one of the authors of a 2014 HRW report that alleged abuses with some terrorism arrests.

Lutchman is going to prison. He pleaded guilty to the crimes. But, at his sentencing, the dual portrayals will be the terrain for legal arguments, the determining factor in just how severe his sentence will be.

"Without the assistance of (an FBI informant), the planned attack could never have gotten off the ground to begin with," Lutchman's attorney, Assistant Federal Public Defender Steven Slawinski wrote in pre-sentencing court papers.

Federal authorities say Lutchman was on a path to a terrorism crime, and communicated online with a well-known ISIL recruiter, Abu Issa Al-Amriki, who planted the seeds for the New Year's Eve plan. Al-Amriki even told Lutchman to make the video that would be found after the attack, Assistant U.S. Attorney Brett Harvey said in court papers.

"A person like this defendant — a convicted violent felon who ascribes to an extremist ideology and is open to overtures from an overseas terrorist organization — is precisely the type of person that would agree to and actually commit a terrorist attack in the United States," Harvey wrote.
Mental illness and crime

Lutchman, 26, led a transient life, shuttled between different relatives after his mother died when he was 2 years old. He suffered from learning disabilities as well as mental illnesses —  he would later be diagnosed with depression, bipolar disorder and "suicidal ideation" —  and left school in the eighth grade.

According to court papers, he had several "mental hygiene" arrests as an adult and was once institutionalized at the Elmira Psychiatric Center. He was known to patrons of the Merchants Grill as a man who aggressively panhandled outside.
In prison, Lutchman was exposed to a radical brand of Islam and "was easy prey for the other inmates who were preaching it," Slawinski said in court papers.
According to the FBI and prosecutors, Lutchman began interacting with the ISIL recruiter in December 2015. He was told that, to join ISIL overseas, he needed to prove himself, court papers say.

Two FBI informants were able to also communicate with Lutchman, and learned of his plan.  One of the informants went with Lutchman to Walmart on Hudson Avenue, and the informant paid about $40 for two black ski masks, two knives, a machete, zip ties, duct tape, ammonia and latex gloves.

On Dec. 30, Lutchman made the video, stating that  "ISIL was going to establish the caliphate in the land of Islam." Shortly after recording the video, he was arrested by members of a joint anti-terrorism task force that had been monitoring his activities.
"All that remained to successfully carry out the attack was for the defendant to show up at the target," Harvey wrote in court papers.
When are they dangerous?

In June, Omar Mateen massacred 49 people in a mass shooting at a gay nightclub in Orlando, Florida. The FBI had earlier monitored Mateen for months, but made no headway in determining the likelihood that he would carry out an attack.

"They had sources that ran him and tried to get him in conversations," former FBI supervisor Ahearn said. "The guy didn't bite. That's your worst nightmare: The guy's not going to discuss it and stays away from everybody."

Earlier this month, Esteban Santiago fatally shot five people in an airport baggage area in Fort Lauderdale, Florida, authorities allege. Two months before he had walked into an Alaska FBI office with an ammunition clip and complained of a CIA plot against him. Later, he was placed in a psychiatric facility for a short time.
In both crimes, the FBI's decision-making came into question: Could the bureau have done more?
For Ahearn, the crimes show the difficulty in determining just who will take the major criminal steps and who won't. "It's a fine line," he said. "There's no doubt it's a fine line."

Legally, the suspect has to show a willingness to commit the crimes, absent intervention from police informants or law enforcement. Informants and undercover cops can help advance a criminal plot —  they do so in many drug cases —  but cannot steer an unwilling participant toward the act.

"It's almost impossible to prove entrapment in U.S. law and doubly impossible to prove it in a terrorism case," said HRW's Prasow. Juries do not look favorably on a person willing to commit terrorism, even if the accused would not have done so without law enforcement encouragement, she said.

In his court papers, defense attorney Skawinski contended that, "While not a perfect case of entrapment, Lutchman would have never been able to take any of the substantial actions in the conspiracy (for example, buying the implements at Walmart, mounting an attack at the restaurant) without the assistance of (an informant) who was working with the FBI."

Slawinski plans to ask for a 10-year sentence for Lutchman, followed by "a significant term of supervised release." Harvey, the prosecutor, is requesting a 20-year sentence, with lifelong post-release supervision.
While Lutchman may have mental health issues, "there has been no claim in this case that the defendant did not understand the nature of his criminal acts," Harvey wrote.
Lutchman said in a letter to U.S. District Judge Frank Geraci Jr., who will decide Lutchman's sentence, that he has renounced ISIL.
"This plot was a twisted intentioned (sic)," he wrote.
"I wish I never had created it in my heart and mind."
GCRAIG@Gannett.com

articleBody.value: David C. Munson Jr. has been selected as the next president of Rochester Institute of Technology.
The naming of Munson, 64, who will take office in July, was announced Wednesday, before a crowd at the Gordon Field House and Activities Center on the RIT campus in Henrietta.

The selection ends a search that took shape in June, after RIT President Bill Destler said that he will be stepping down at the end of this school year. Destler, 70, is completing a decade as president.
Munson, a former dean of engineering at the University of Michigan, will become the 10th president in RIT history. Munson is currently on sabbatical from Michigan.
In his introduction address, Munson identified with RIT's priorities.
"I resonate strongly with your ethos as a student-centered research university," he said.
He also praised RIT for leveraging historic strengths of Rochester — imaging, science and digital media.
"More broadly, I share your passion for creativity, innovation and collaboration."
Munson also talked about the importance of access and inclusion.

"Our goal will be that students' return on investment will come not only in the material form of future earnings, but also their ability to affect positive change, contribute to the social good, and continue on a path of lifelong learning and service."
RIT, which has a history that dates to 1829 with the establishment of an Athenaeum in Rochester, has evolved into an institution of higher learning with almost 19,000 students.

Munson will be taking the reins of a college that has experienced sharp growth in enrollment and rise in prestige. Last year, the Carnegie Classification of Institutions of Higher Education reclassified RIT as a doctoral university, reflecting the increasing number of Ph.D.'s it has awarded.

RIT not only has become the college with the largest student body in the Rochester area, but also has become the 10th largest private university in the United States, in terms of full-time undergraduate enrollment.
The 24-member Presidential Search Committee that headed up the selection was assisted by the Boston-based search firm, Isaacson, Miller.
RIT’s board of trustees made the final selection.
Board chairman Christine Whitman said the original pool of applicants included a couple of hundred names.

Among the qualities that Isaacson, Miller set forth in a “Search for a President” profile paper were enthusiasm for RIT's student-centered, technology-focused mission and an appreciation for maintaining a balance between research and high quality teaching and learning as well as a familiarity with technology.
JGOODMAN@Gannett.com

content.author: James Goodman, @goodman_dandc

articleBody.value: A man was killed in a work-related accident in Lakeville, Livingston County, on Wednesday morning.
Livingston County Undersheriff Matthew Bean said a worker fell into a covered hopper loaded with granular fertilizer and died.
Emergency dispatchers received a 911 call about 10:20 a.m. for person who had fallen into a covered hopper near Smith Lumber & Hardware Center on Big Tree Road in Lakeville.
Authorities are attempting to recover the worker's body and are investigating to determine what happened, Bean said. The man's name was not released, pending family notification.
VFREILE@Gannett.com
TYEE@Gannett.com

content.author: Victoria E. Freile, and Tina MacIntyre-Yee, Democrat and Chronicle

articleBody.value: More than 100 puppies bound for local pet stores were rescued from an overturned van on Interstate 86 in Steuben County on Tuesday.
State police out of the Bath barracks responded to a motor vehicle crash in the eastbound lane of I-86 in Avoca at 8:12 a.m.

Thirty-year-old Emily Woodrum, of Webb City, Missouri, was transporting the dogs in a box van to local pet stores when the crash occurred, according to police. Woodrum was driving at an unsafe speed while in the passing lane when she lost control of the vehicle and went off the southbound shoulder, striking a ditch before overturning, according to a news release.
Troopers Mark Bernard, Jordan Sheehan and Pete Peters removed all the puppies from the van. Five puppies sustained minor injuries but were quickly treated by the Steuben County SPCA, police said.
T & R Towing assisted at the scene.
Follow @theSGphotos   on Twitter or on Instagram @kelly.gampel

content.author: Kelly Gampel, kgampel@stargazette.com | @theSGphotos

articleBody.value: — Our editors review and recommend products to help you buy the stuff you need. If you make a purchase by clicking one of our links, we may earn a small share of the revenue. Our picks and opinions are independent from any business incentives.

Originally based in California, Vizio—who was acquired by Chinese tech company LeEco in 2016—has in recent years established a very strong presence in the 4K and smart TV markets. Vizio's TV series tend to deliver the year's cutting-edge TV features without the razor-sharp prices.

While Vizio generally doesn't produce as many "series" as competitors Samsung and LG, the company's lineups tend to be available in a huge range of sizes, often with variable screen resolution or smart features to help consumers maximize value by only paying for what they need.

Generally, Vizio TVs come in a few "core" series: the D, E, M, and P Series, which run the gamut from budget-friendly to high-end, respectively. There's also a Reference Series from 2015 that Vizio continues to produce as its flagship.
Best Overall — Vizio P Series (2016)

While it's not the most technically decked out TV that Vizio's ever made, the 2016 P Series—available in 50-, 55-, 65-, and 75-inch screen sizes and starting at a very palatable $999—exemplifies the company's crossroads of quality and affordability.

The 2016 P Series TVs deliver 4K/UHD resolution (3,840 x 2,160), High Dynamic Range (HDR) compatibility including HDR10 and Dolby Vision, full-array local dimming backlights, and a Chromecast-based "Vizio SmartCast" system that allows every function of the TV to be controlled via a second-screen device.

Forget that it's not quite as bright nor as snazzy overall as the flagship Reference Series (which is $6,000)—the 2016 P Series is the best overall choice for most people. This series boasts above-average HDR and 4K picture quality at very agreeable prices. Read the full review of the Vizio P Series (2016)
Where to Buy:
• $1,299.00 at Dell
Best Performance — Vizio Reference Series

The Vizio Reference Series is Vizio's créme de la créme, flagship product, and has been since late 2015. When it debuted, the 65-inch (RS65-B2) was $6,000, while the 120-inch model asked a jaw-dropping $129,000. For most people the 65-inch is the only real option.

That said, the 65-inch still knocked our socks off when we got it into the lab in early 2016. For six grand, you're getting a whopping 65-inch TV; HDR and Dolby Vision compatibility about 800 nits of brightness; a quantum dot film for wide color gamut; an included 8-inch Android tablet; and full-array local dimming with 384 zones.

The RS65 also includes an entire surround sound system, with soundbar, tweeters, and a subwoofer. The heavy metal finish really seals the deal. On the other hand, while technically it's Vizio's highest performing product, its HDR brightness/color specs are already being notably outpaced by 2017 sets. Read the full review of the Vizio Reference Series (2016)
Where to Buy:
• $5,999.99 at Vizio
Vizio M Series (2016)

There's no denying the tech- and filigree-heavy Reference Series is too expensive for most folks, but even the best overall 2016 P Series might boast a bit more fancy than you're looking for. Never fear, Vizio's 2016 M Series—the "midrange" one—fills in the gaps.

Available in a huge range of sizes—50, 55, 60, 65, 70, and 80 inches starting at $849—the M Series brings a bunch of forward-facing tech like 4K resolution, the SmartCast system and included tablet, HDR compatibility, and full-array local dimming backlighting.

While it isn't as bright and flashy as the step-up 2016 P Series, this is the one to go for if you mostly want a good deal on a 4K TV but don't want to miss out on HDR. Read the full review of the Vizio M Series (2016)
Where to Buy:

• $1,299.99 at Best Buy
  • $1,298.00 at Walmart
Vizio E Series (2016)

Vizio's E Series continues to be one of the better TV values out there, and thankfully—like the much more posh P Series TVs—each E Series model this year (4K or not) delivers solid picture quality. They're not quite the M Series, but these are solid all-around TVs.

Depending on which model, you'll get either 720p, 1080p, or 4K resolution, but each is equipped with the SmartCast system and full-array LED backlighting with variable local dimming zones depending upon screen size.

The E Series is available in a whopping number of screen sizes—15 or so, starting from a 720p 32-inch model for around $200 through a 4K 70-inch model for $1,300. But no matter how to slice the screen size, the prices tend to be very good. Read the full review of the Vizio E Series (2016)
Where to Buy:

• $799.99 at Best Buy
  • $848.00 at Walmart
Vizio D Series (2016)

Last but not at all least, the 2016 Vizio D Series is the company's bottom-of-the-barrel, super cheap entry. But as we discovered, that doesn't mean the D Series TVs aren't good—they make the cut, albeit they cut corners in places, too.

Like the 2016 E Series, the D Series is available in a bunch of sizes—25, to be exact—with a dizzying amount of variability from the cheapest (a 24-inch, 720p "dumb" TV for $149) to the most expensive (a 65-inch 4K smart TV for $1,200).

This series, while a great way to maximize affordability, can admittedly be a little confusing; Fortunately, we have a handy guide for figuring out which one you're buying. Scan through the guide before you pull the trigger, just to be safe. Read the full review of the Vizio D Series (2016)
Where to Buy:

• $1,182.70 at Amazon
  • $1,287.47 at Walmart

articleBody.value: Andrea Brown said she had to pay $134 for an office visit with her primary care physician when she had a high-deductible health plan.

“It can be unbudgeted money you can’t afford,” said 50-year-old Brown, who qualified when New York expanded Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act. Under her plan now, she said she pays $20 for an office visit.
As President Trump and the Republican-led Congress start to address the ACA, aka Obamacare, Brown had a requirement for whatever they end up doing to health insurance.
“Have it affordable for people who actually need it,” she said. “A lot of people will be left without health care, and that’s kind of frightening.”
Most experts won’t go out on a limb and say what new legislation will look like. But they, like consumers, have a wish list.

“You typically hear repeal,” said Amy Pollard, president and chief executive officer of Noyes Health and chair of the Rochester Regional Healthcare Advocates, part of a health system association that serves Monroe and seven other counties. “Repeal what?, is the big question. And replace with what is the even bigger question.”
In conversations with several people who use or administer health care, these were common themes:

►Continue to cover people with pre-existing conditions and continue the ban on annual or lifetime caps on coverage. Ideally, you’d want such plans to have a reasonable premium. But that may depend on …

►… convincing younger, healthy people to get coverage. The mix is crucial. Even when it's nonprofit, health insurance is a business. The idea of the individual mandate in the ACA was to get people who pay premiums but don’t use much health care to pay for the people who use a lot of care. According to one account, the rate of 18- to 34-year-olds was below the 40 percent threshold that actuaries say is required to keep premiums stable. It’s apparent that the threat of a tax penalty didn’t scare the so-called “invincibles” into buying health coverage. Something else will have to encourage people who don’t think they need health insurance into protecting their health, just as they buy insurance to protect their belongings or their car. Or the money that the government and insurers counted on will have to come from a different source.
►Keep kids up to 26 on their parents’ plan. It will get them used to having insurance, which may encourage them to buy their own policies when they age off their parents’ plan.

►Promote healthy lifestyles. The ACA lets you get a flu shot and an annual wellness checkup without having to dig into your pocket. But more has to be done to prevent the toll that chronic disease takes on families and on the health care system.  Heart disease is the No. 1 killer of Americans, and a portion of cases can be prevented. If things keep going the way they have, by 2030 it'll cost $818 billion to treat heart disease. Diabetes, the seventh leading cause of death, costs on average $85,000 per case. It costs about $200 billion to treat the estimated 26 million people with the disease.
►Boost primary care to keep people healthy and manage disease early, both of which save money in the long run.

►Limit payouts on pain and suffering in malpractice suits. Health care execs said this could reduce malpractice premiums. This also could reduce the practice of defensive medicine, when doctors order tests out of fear of being sued if they don’t, and a problem surfaces later.

►Avoid making emergency rooms more crowded. Locally and nationally, there has been a push for people to see their primary care doctor, go to an urgent care center or use telemedicine when they had a problem that wasn’t life-threatening. One concern is that if people lose coverage, they will go to emergency departments where they have to at least be stabilized — regardless of their ability to pay.
PSINGER@Gannett.com

articleBody.value: Balance the beer, balance your life.
Kristi and Tommy Streamer, the married owners of the Amber Lantern Brewing Co. in Warsaw, Wyoming County, believe this simple philosophy guides them.
It's how they balance a young family, running a small business, and operating Wyoming County's first craft brewery.
“I’m the boss and she’s the big boss,” Tommy, 46, jokes.

“Between the two of us, we have to be able to do every single thing in this business,” Kristi, 47, said. “I don’t know anything about brewing beer, but between the two of us, there isn’t anything we couldn’t do. We can rely on each other.
"It’s a big thing to take on, to work with your spouse every day."
The Streamers have been married for almost 15 years. The last six years have been spent together at the Amber Lantern, 44 N. Main St.

Before the Streamers purchased the Amber Lantern, it was owned for 25 years by Kristi's parents, Ron and Cyndy Smith. The bar has been part of the village's fabric since the 1950s. The building that houses it predates 1900.
“This place has probably employed half the town at some point,” Tommy said. “Our whole mission was make a better Amber Lantern, with the idea of eventually adding the brewpub later on."

They installed a 1.5-barrel brewhouse (with three fermenters) in a tight space that formerly housed an office and started brewing under a farm brewery license in May 2015. (Tommy estimates ALBC uses over 90 percent New York-grown ingredients and relies heavily on malt from Batavia's New York Craft Malt.) Tommy even did a two-week intensive brewing class through the prestigious Seibel Institute in Chicago.

Kristi said the goal of ALBC has always been quality and consistency. They also wanted to push toward more craft-centric offerings. ALBC maintains an on-premise liquor license, which allows them to offer beers such as Stella Artois, Guinness and Blue Moon. But the Streamers have slowly introduced new options and new flavor profiles.
READ MORE:
► First craft brewery opens in Livingston County
► Ranking Rochester's recent IPAs
“I use this phrase all the time,” Tommy said. “We’re trying to get this little squirrel to come over to us. And certainly in this town, it’s like, ‘Try this, try this.’”

"It worked, slow and steady," Kristi added. "This place has been owned by so many different people and so many different people have worked here, we couldn’t just shock everybody and flip it upside down.”

They did the same with the menu. Previously, the Amber Lantern was only open for lunch and Friday dinners. The Streamers expanded hours and offerings. Now, there is a focus on fresh pub-style food. (The burgers are fantastic.) Again, balance is key. A lot of the meals pair exceedingly well with the well-crafted beers.

Tommy and brewer Ben Bernard produce well-crafted, simple beers. ALBC makes the kind of beers that you can enjoy during a conversation with a good friend. You become engrossed in the conversation and the beer perfectly pairs with that, because there aren't any extreme adjuncts or ingredients to distract you.

ALBC usually has between three and five beers on draft. The Wee Heavy Scotch Ale is a hearty sipper. There is also a hoppy blonde ale, a fruited wheat (with a nice cranberry tartness on the finish), and the flagship amber ale.

The Tiger India pale ale (named after Warsaw High School's mascot) is a quintessential New York-brewed IPA. The first sip is a bit jarring as you're hit with some unexpected, but not unpleasant, bitterness. But then you acclimate to it and it becomes a full-bodied IPA with a nice dryness in the finish, a citrusy hop character, a sweet malt backbone, and pleasant lingering bitterness.
READ MORE:
► Selecting New York's 10 best breweries
► Best beers during a memorable 2016

ALBC is currently one of 15 finalists in the Brew in Livingston business plan competition. Four winners will each be awarded $35,000 in state grant money in March to help create a Livingston County craft beer trail.

If the Streamers win, they would look to open a second ALBC location in Geneseo. This one would have a five- or seven-barrel brewhouse and feature a taproom. Even if they don't win, they still could open a second location. But again, the progress will be slow and controlled.

"It’s got to be done smartly," Tommy said. "I think everyone has seen businesses that try to grow and go too far with things that aren’t realistic. We don’t have to do anything. We’re doing fine in Warsaw. We love it. We just feel like maybe we want to."

"And we’re starting to feel confident that we’re capable of doing it," Kristi finished. "Our support network, our family, our staff, all of that has come together and it coincides with this competition. It’s really fortuitous."
WCLEVELAND@Gannett.com

articleBody.value: Welcome to the Democrat and Chronicle’s Coffee Break Concert. Rochester vibrates with sound. So we’ve created a video series in which you can hear and see some of our area’s intriguing musicians.

We’ve carefully removed these creative creatures from their natural environment — the bars, coffee shops, sidewalks and other public venues of the city — and brought them to D&C Digital studio at 245 E. Main St. There, we subjected them to routine brain scans, tests of motor skills and screenings for potentially antisocial behavior, handed them a cup of coffee and asked for just two songs.

Today, it’s Connie Deming. She’s been compared to Joni Mitchell. But that’s not quite the right fit. The singer-songwriter is one of a kind. She’s more like a woodland sprite, flitting around the notes like leaves on a tree, moving with the breeze. Here she performs two of her original songs, “She Said” and “The Quilt Song.”
JSPEVAK@Gannett.com

articleBody.value: As an alternative, critic Jack Garner recommends:

The Man Who Fell to Earth: This is a mysterious and intriguing British sci-fi film that has become part of the David Bowie mystique. Bowie plays a humanoid alien who comes to earth in search of water for his drought-stricken planet. Pretending to be a human (but with super-human intelligence), he quickly becomes head of a technology-based conglomerate. There's also romance with a sweet, simple and lonely girl (Candy Clark) from whom he learns the ways of earthlings, including religion, booze and sex. Meanwhile, a professor (Rip Torn) becomes his confidant, but begins to suspect his alien nature. All in all, it is a strange but highly original film. It's adapted from a novel by Walter Tevis, who also wrote the extremely different novelo, The Hustler, which was the source material for the great Paul Newman picture.
Director:  Nicolas Roeg.
Cast: Bowie, Clark, Torn.
Jack’s rating: 9.

New on DVD this week: The Man Who Fell to Earth (Blu-ray), Wait Until Dark (Blu-ray), Sherlock: Season 4, USS Indianapolis, The Light Between Oceans, I'm Not Ashamed, Poltergeist III and Boy Did I Get a Wrong Number.
Next week:Disney's Pinocchio (Blu-ray), Bells Are Ringing, The Lair of the White Worm, Parents, Masterminds, Victoria: Season 1, Dr. Feelgood, Tyler Perry's Madea on the Run and Silk: Season 3.

articleBody.value: The sorriest bus stop is finally getting a makeover.

Workers have started installing a concrete pad at the Regional Transit Service site on Hylan Drive in Henrietta near Wegmans, where riders used to have to wait for buses while standing on a dirt plot with no seating or protection from the elements.
Once that is completed, the planned shelter should go up in a week or two, said RTS spokesperson Tom Brede.

The bus stop was featured as a finalist last summer in national blog StreetsBlogUSA’s competition for the nation’s “sorriest bus stops,” which were nominated by online readers across the country. The bus stop was already in line for an overhaul at the time, said Brede. A bus shelter was already provided at a stop across the street, near Marketplace Mall.

When it comes to accessing the bus shelter, Hylan Drive does not have sidewalks on either side of it. RTS prefers that a property owner or municipality build sidewalks around bus shelters for accessibility, but it is not a requirement, and RTS is not taking the lead to install sidewalks on either side of Hylan Drive, said Brede.
Henrietta town officials could not be immediately reached Wednesday on whether the town plans to build sidewalks there in the future.
STADDEO@Gannett.com

articleBody.value: ALBANY -- New York already had the largest lottery in the nation. And it just got bigger.
Revenue from the state Lottery and its nine racetracks with video-lottery terminals grew nearly 5 percent between 2015 and 2016, state records show.
The increase was fueled by a $1.5 billion Powerball jackpot a year ago, plus gains in Quick Draw and instant-lottery games, the records obtained by the USA Today's Albany Bureau showed.
New York's lottery revenue reached a record $9.8 billion last year, a nearly $441 million increase from 2015.
Five of the nine so-called racinos also posted gains, including Batavia Downs and Finger Lakes in western New York and Empire City at Yonkers Raceway.
Empire City's net win -- the amount of money left in the machines after pay outs to winners -- led the state, growing 5.6 percent over the year to nearly $590 million, the records showed.
“Empire City is proud of our growth but takes nothing for granted," said Timothy Rooney Jr., the track's general counsel, in a statement.
Dollar and a dream
Powerball sales soared 77 percent in 2016 to $537 million, while sales of Quick Draw -- which added bonus payout promotions last year -- grew 7.5 percent.
Overall, lottery games' sales increased 5 percent, while the racinos grew 3.2 percent.
The growth of the lottery and the racinos comes amid increasing competition for gambling revenue in New York and the region -- which several companies noted.

The state is in the middle of adding four full-scale casinos: Tioga Downs in the Southern Tier reopened as a full casino last month, and ones in Schenectady and the Finger Lakes are set to open next month.
One in the Catskills, Montreign, is scheduled to open next year.
Tioga Downs' net win fell 4.6 percent last year before it changed over from a racino to a casino in December after receiving a casino license earlier in the year.
The owner, Jeff Gural, also had a weak year at the Vernon Downs racino in central New York amid expansions by the Oneida Indian Nation at its nearby Turning Stone Casino and Resort.
More competition
The Oneidas added a new casino, Yellow Brick Road, near Syracuse in preparation of the del Lago casino opening in the Finger Lakes, a move that hurt Vernon Downs, Gural said.
Gural said Tioga Downs' numbers picked up in December after the re-opening, leading to higher gains overall for the year.

For Vernon Downs, though, Gural said he's asking the state for a better tax rate to compete with the Oneidas, saying Vernon Downs employs 300 people and supports the horse-racing industry because of its harness track.

"Hopefully we will succeed this year in getting relief as it does not cost the state anything," Gural said. "Our customers are simply going elsewhere in the state to gamble, and the state receives that revenue."
Last year, the state improved the tax rate for Finger Lakes because of the looming opening of del Lago, and now Finger Lakes wants help to pay its expenses to run its thoroughbred track.
VLT revenue
Finger Lakes finished the year with its net win up 1.2 percent compared to 2015, at nearly $129 million.
Batavia Downs was up 1.6 percent, to $53.4 million.
Hamburg Gaming fell off 1.3 percent, while Resorts World at Aqueduct racetrack in Queens -- which brings in the most revenue in the state -- dropped less than 1 percent to $826 million.
Empire City said the state should move forward with plans to allow downstate racinos to open as full-scale casinos with table games.
Now, they only have electronic table games to go with the slot-machine-like devices.
In 2013, voters approved allowing the state to open up to seven privately owned casinos. Yet the state agreed to open the first four outside the New York City area.
"Competition is increasing with full-gaming casinos opening in New York and more to come in neighboring states," Rooney said.
"Empire City looks forward to securing a full gaming license in the near future, the economic implications of which are endless both regionally and for all of New York.”

articleBody.value: Rochester police have identified the two women who died Tuesday afternoon following a two-car crash on Lake Avenue.

Kesha Knight, 42, and her passenger, Shakira Howard, 22, were both killed in the incident. Police said that Knight was driving an SUV that appeared to have lost control, swerving into the oncoming lane. It was struck by a white pickup truck that was northbound.
The incident occurred around 2:20 p.m. near Riverside Cemetery.
The driver of the pickup, 34 year old Amanda Thomas, suffered non-life threatening injuries, and was transported to Strong Memorial Hospital.
All three women are city residents.
Lake Avenue was closed for several hours Tuesday while investigators were working at the scene.
SLAHMAN@Gannett.com

articleBody.value: Gates Police Officer Lance Duffy drove himself to Strong Memorial Hospital Tuesday evening after suffering a heart attack.
Duffy, 53, an officer with the department for more than three decades, was off-duty at the time and had just finished refereeing a hockey game, said Gates Police Chief Jim VanBrederode.
He was feeling ill and drove to Strong, VanBrederode said. He drove up to the front door when his heart stopped.
"Security officers saw him pull in, went to the car and saw he was slumped over the wheel," VanBrederode said. "They had to smash his car window to pull him out."

Hospital employees started CPR and shocked his heart in the Emergency Department before he underwent surgery, he said. His medical prognosis remains unknown at this time, though doctors are optimistic since CPR was started immediately.
Duffy is in a medically-induced coma and will be for at least 36 hours before doctors attempt to wake him to check for brain activity, VanBrederode said.
"Everything we tell people not to do, he did," VanBrederode said, calling Duffy's trek to Strong "classic form."
Duffy is the department's public information officer and the brainchild behind the department's wildly popular hug-a-cop event at Wal-Mart last summer.
"He's the face of the department," VanBrederode said, adding that Duffy is well-known and well-loved throughout the community.
VFREILE@Gannett.com

articleBody.value: We start in 1965, and Tony Trischka was a teenage banjo whiz from Syracuse, playing the traditional bluegrass number “Nine Pound Hammer” at a competition in Virginia. “Right in the midst of it I put in some pseudo-Middle Eastern modal stuff,” he says. “One of the judges was Ralph Stanley.
“Needless to say, I didn’t do very well.”

Decades later, the world of traditional banjo has gotten over it. Today, Trischka is at the top of the list, or sometimes right behind Béla Fleck, as the most-respected and innovative banjo strummer in the world.
How much can a banjoist — it’s a real word, you can look it up — do with five strings?

In 1986, the modern composer and fellow banjoist Paul Elwood summoned Trischka to Kansas to play on a piece Elwood had written called “The Void Beneath the Coffee Table.” A five-piece percussion ensemble accompanied by keyboards and harp. Trischka’s assignment: Play the banjo with a bow. And also, play it like a slide guitarist might, except instead of gliding a cylinder along the neck, use a glass ashtray. “Totally atonal, bizarre, crazy, crazy stuff,” Trischka says.

Trischka has not since set ashtray to strings, although he’s confident he could once again summon the skill, if asked. Perhaps if someone brings an ashtray to his solo show Jan. 27 at Bernunzio Uptown Music. Just a suggestion.

Trischka grew up in a house where his parents’ music was Pete Seeger, but also Broadway tunes and jazz, such as Fats Waller. The first time he picked up a banjo, inspired by a Kingston Trio recording, Trischka plucked out the melody to Beethoven’s “Ode to Joy.” That was 1963; he was 14 years old. “I heard it in my head and found the notes,” he says. “Even from the very beginning I wasn’t strictly bluegrass.”

Now, at 68, he sometimes is, sometimes isn’t. There was room for plenty in his formative years. “The Beatles, hipper stuff,” Trischka says.  “Hendrix, Zappa, jazz. The Mahavishnu Orchestra, Chick Corea. It all had time to ferment.”

The result is an intoxicating blend of playing with folk icons such as Peter Rowan and helping to create music for an off-Broadway production of Driving Miss Daisy. Trischka’s backed the gravelly, wheedling narration of the writer William Burroughs and accompanied The Violent Femmes. He’s done the proper radio shows, A Prairie Home Companion and Mountain Stage. And recorded with the Bill Monroe and Ralph Stanley, the two men Trischka calls “the epicenter of bluegrass.”

Trischka passes on this vast experience as a Yoda of the banjo. His many instructional books and videos are the stone tablets handed down from his home in Fair Lawn, New Jersey. Mostly amateurs. He did have one 16-year-old kid come to him for lessons, but, “Within a few months, it was obvious this guy didn’t need lessons anymore.”

Yeah, Béla Fleck. That’s OK. Trischka’s hardly out of work. In 2007, he recruited a handful of notable banjo players — Earl Scruggs, Béla Fleck, Tony Rice — for Double Banjo Bluegrass Spectacular, an album that revived the old double-banjo tradition. It was nominated for a Grammy.

A few years later, one of the musicians on Double Banjo Bluegrass Spectacular asked Trischka to do some pre-production work on his next album. The guy had once been a comedian who played banjo while wearing an arrow through his head. Trischka wasn’t fooled. “I’d seen a video of him playing at some big function, and he was very serious,” Trischka says. “It was this very beautiful song, but people started chuckling and laughing. Because it’s Steve Martin.”

Trischka went on to produce Martin’s second album as well. They lined up some guests for Rare Bird Alert — Paul McCartney, the Dixie Chicks and the Steep Canyon Rangers — and it was nominated for a Grammy.

That’s the crowd that Trischka runs with. And of course, there is a Bob Dylan story. In 1963, the country was just starting to catch wind of Dylan. Trischka’s banjo teacher had a copy of Dylan’s first album, and it was autographed. His teacher knew Bob Dylan!

“He took me to a concert, and we got backstage,” Trischka says. “I remember shaking his hand; he had really long fingernails. He invited us to his hotel across the street. Just me, my teacher and his wife. Dylan asked me, ‘Would you like something to drink?’ And he went down the hall and got me a Coke.
“He was very sweet. This was before he got too famous. But that’s my Dylan story. He got me a Coke.”

And now? Trischka asked one of Dylan’s band members whether he could see Dylan after a show in Binghamton. “He just said, ‘Yeah, ahh, Bob doesn’t do that.’ He stays to himself. Even when you’re connected, you don’t see him.”

Get your own Coke, kid. But Trischka confesses he’s remained a huge fan. “I know almost every song he ever did,” Trischka says. “I have virtually every album.” Out of this came one of his latest musical ventures: Trischka’s Bob Dylan tribute band, Early Roman Kings, named for one of Dylan’s songs. The bassist, Jared Engel, is from Rochester. It is a rare moment away from the banjo, with Trischka playing pedal steel guitar. “I literally had not played it in 35 years,” he says. “I took it out of mothballs.”

Trischka’s newest work is an album he calls the Civil War Project, which he plans to release this year. “It’s something I’ve been working at the last seven, eight years,” he says. “It’s two-thirds of the way done.” And, something he hasn’t done much of, he’s writing lyrics for it. “The world really doesn’t need another banjo instrumental,” he says. Maybe jokingly.

The Civil War Project uses Jimmie Rodgers’ songs as a template, and weaves in stories of a train robbery, a woman who emigrated from Ireland to escape the Irish potato famine of 1848, meeting a riverboat gambler who becomes a soldier in the Civil War.

During the course of writing, Trischka visited a graveyard for slaves outsideAshville, North Carolina, and heard the story of a slave named George Avery. “He was a gravedigger at the plantation. He buried the dead in wicker baskets and put stones without inscriptions over them,” Trischka says. “So it’s just a field of rocks. It was so intense.”

Further studies revealed that while there were no black regiments at the Battle of Gettysburg, there was a black man who picked up a gun to fight for the Union army. Through Trischka’s artistic license, that man becomes Avery.
The music includes banjo, of course, and “an eight-piece brass band in the style of the Civil War,” Trischka says. “And some spoken word from that time.”
This sounds like a banjo concept album. “It’s pretty much a concept album,” Trischka agrees. “But I don’t want it to sound pretentious.”
So with all of this exploration of new banjo worlds, can Trischka still find satisfaction in just picking?

“Totally. I do it every day,” he says. Some of that is due to his online banjo school, where students submit internet videos of their playing and he responds. The students tend to stick to the banjo basics. “It keeps me grounded,” he says.
Indeed, no matter how far a banjo strays, the bluegrass community tends to stay on Appalachian grounds. The music creates profound moments all its own.

As with The Wayfaring Strangers, an all-star bluegrass ensemble featuring Trischka. Lots of guests have joined the band, and for its 2001 album Shifting Sands of Time it called on Ralph Stanley to sing on a track. The perfect opportunity for Trischka to remind the bluegrass legend of how he’d rejected the 18-year-old’s pseudo-Middle Eastern take on “Nine Pound Hammer.”

Trischka let it pass. His bruised teenage ego wasn’t enough to ruin the moment. “We were recording ‘Man of Constant Sorrow,’” Trischka says. “Hearing Ralph’s voice inside my head, with the headphones on, singing that, was one of the most remarkable experiences of my life.”
If you go
What: Tony Trischka.
When: 8 p.m. Jan. 27.
Where:  Bernunzio Uptown Music, 122 East Ave.
Tickets: $18 advance, $20 at the door, $15 for students, available at counter@bernunzio.com, (585) 473-6140 or the store.

articleBody.value: ALBANY - The number of school districts facing fiscal stress dropped to its lowest level last year since the state Comptroller's Office began tracking it four years ago, according to a report released Wednesday.

A total of 59 school districts across the state -- or 9 percent -- faced some level of budgetary stress during the 2015-16 school year, with just two districts showing "significant" stress, the report from Comptroller Thomas DiNapoli showed.
It marked a significant drop from the previous school year, when 82 districts -- or 12 percent -- showed fiscal stress.
► 35 local governments show fiscal stress
► From 2015: 13 percent of districts show fiscal stress
► Broome County cited for fiscal stress

“Fiscal stress in many school districts has declined, especially for those in the most severe condition,” DiNapoli said in a statement. “School officials should be commended for working to keep their districts out of financial harm, but should be careful not to amass excessive levels of fund balance in order to do so.”

DiNapoli's office launched a monitoring system in 2012 that rates each school district's budget on a variety of fiscal factors, giving each a score based on their end-of-year balances, deficits and borrowing habits.
Each district is then rated as showing significant stress, moderate stress or being susceptible to fiscal stress. If they are showing no signs of budgetary trouble, they are given no designation.
DiNapoli's report Wednesday focused on the 671 districts with fiscal years that ended June 30.
Only the Hempstead and Wyandanch districts on Long Island received a "significant" ranking, down from eight districts in 2014-15.

Nine districts showed moderate fiscal stress, according to DiNapoli's office. Among them were Bedford in Westchester County and East Ramapo in Rockland County. East Ramapo dropped from the "significant" rating it received in 2014-15.
Forty-eight districts were "susceptible to fiscal stress," the report showed, including Rhinebeck in Dutchess County, New Rochelle in Westchester County and Gates-Chili in Monroe County.

content.author: Jon Campbell, @JonCampbellGAN
content.headline: DiNapoli: Fewer NY schools face fiscal stress

articleBody.value: At a small church in Hamlin last week, Stephen Johnson asked a group of friends to pray for him as he faced a deeply personal struggle.

I was there. I mentally committed to remember him in prayer that week, and many of our dozen or so friends who were present and had been meeting with the tight-knit, weekly bible study group for over a year did the same.

But only one person immediately jumped up and asked to pray for Johnson. With a hand on Johnson’s shoulder, she asked God to guide him through pain and uncertainty, and inspired the rest of us to follow her lead.
That person was Rebekah Hoak, and that was one of the last times I saw her. She died Sunday in a car crash in Kendall, Orleans County, while bringing a meal to a close friend.

“That last moment at life group (the bible study group) with her, she was just herself,” said Johnson, of Greece. “There’s a relationship with God that you can ‘put on’…but it’s kind of hard to be genuinely personable and genuinely the one that jumps up to pray for people.”

It was incredibly fitting that Rebekah’s last few days were filled with acts of service and kindness. At 20 years old, the Holley, Orleans County, resident had touched more lives than most do in a lifetime of seven or eight decades.

For me, she was a streak of joy that would instantly make every Monday evening I spent with her a better evening. She was quick to offer encouraging words and, though she was shy, she was always ready for adventure.

One of the experiences Rebekah and I shared last summer was competing in the long-standing grease pole competition at the Orleans County 4-H Fair. A friend of ours assembled an all-female team at the last minute, and we worked together to shimmy to the top of a 20-plus-foot pole slathered in grease.

Rebekah’s soft-spoken demeanor would make the average person assume she’d shy away from competition. But she ended up being the linchpin of our team, even as she was (literally) stepped on and covered in gloppy blue grease. And she was still laughing at the end.

On a typical day, you could find Rebekah sipping coffee with friends, baking or cleaning at her house or bringing smiles to her co-workers’ faces while working at a local T.J. Maxx. She was considering attending bible college, but was less focused on her own ambitions as she was on how she could minister to her family, her church, her friends and her community.

She was one of the best examples in my life of faith in action — she wholeheartedly believed that her life had been redeemed by a God who loved her enough to die for her on a cross, and she used the personality and talents she had to bring that love to others.
Rebekah taught me that a God-honoring life is so much more precious and impactful than storing up earthly wealth or success.
Her last Instagram post, uploaded a day before she died, says it all.
The grass withers and the flowers fade, but the word of our God remains forever. -Isaiah 40:8
STADDEO@Gannett.com

content.author: Sarah Taddeo, @sjtaddeo
content.headline: Knowing Rebekah: Holley woman was a special soul
content.description: Rebekah Hoak, 20, died in a car crash in Orleans County Sunday.

articleBody.value: A Chili man is facing a felony driving while intoxicated charge after submerging a car in a drainage ditch.
Eric W. Suarez, 28, was chased down by two passersby who watched him run from the scene on Westside Drive Tuesday night, according to Gates Police. The crash occurred just before 10:30 p.m.

Two motorists who were driving by the scene, saw a man run away from the submerged sedan, officers said. They exited their own vehicles and chased him down. The duo then walked Suarez back to the scene, according to police.
Suarez, who refused a breath test, was previously convicted of DWI in 2008.

Officers urged drivers not to drink alcohol and drive. In this crash, the sedan "could have very easily flipped over when it went into the ditch and the driver could have been upside down in the water."
VFREILE@Gannett.com

content.author: Victoria E. Freile, @vfreile
content.headline: 2 citizens chase down man accused of DWI
content.description: A Chili man allegedly ran after submerging a car in a drainage ditch in Gates late Tuesday.

articleBody.value: Soulful country singer-songwriter Sam Hunt has a 7 p.m. July 23 date at Constellation Brands-Marvin Sands Performing Arts Center.
► MORE: CMAC, Darien Lake announce summer shows

Hunt got his start in Nashville writing songs for Kenny Chesney, Keith Urban, Billy Currington and Reba McEntire. When he broke out on his own, Hunt’s debut album Montevallo went to No. 1 on the Billboard magazine charts on the strength of hits such as “Leave the Night On” and “Take Your Time.”

The supporting acts are Maren Morris, Chris Janson and Ryan Follesse. Tickets ($59 and $49 for the pavilion, $34 advance and $39 the day of the show for the lawn) go on sale at 10 a.m. Feb. 3 at Ticketmaster, (ticketmaster.com, (800) 745-3000 and the Blue Cross Arena box office.
JSPEVAK@gannett.com

articleBody.value: A long-vacant but historic Greece hotel could be razed to make way for a gas station and doughnut shop with a drive-through.
Developers are holding a meeting on Thursday for neighbors who might be affected if the DeMay Hotel site at 3561 Latta Road were redeveloped as a Crosby's convenience store.

Plans are still in the early stages and there are numerous town approvals to secure, but Lou Terragnoli, director of real estate for Lockport-based Reid Petroleum said developers hope to build a 4,800 square-foot six-bay gas station — which will include a significant food service component with sandwiches, pizza and other easy-to-grab edibles. The company has 50 Crosby's stores in western New York.
But, for the gas station to go in, it's likely the hotel must come down.

Built in 1909 in the American Foursquare style, the hotel at 3561 Latta Road has had many names: North Greece Hotel, Morelbach Hotel, Domino Inn, Cosmo Inn, Corner House Inn, and most recently, the DeMay Hotel.

In its heydays, the hotel had "Western New York's Largest Dance Floor" and hosted local bands, bowling clubs and special events. It once had more than a dozen guest rooms, a banquet room with bandstand and a tavern.

But, it's been closed and vacant since early 2000, when the property's owner died. The intervening time has not been kind to the building. The stoops are sagging, the railings are rotted and long-broken windows and doors have left portions of the interior vulnerable to weather and intruders. Court documents show a lien was filed against the property in 2015 by the Town of Greece for $338 for necessary property cleanup.
On a recent weekday, broken glass littered the ground outside and tattered blinds flapped in the empty windows.
According to court records, there is a lien against the property for $338 by the town of Greece for property cleanup done in August 2015.
The property has a two-story 9,523 square-foot building on .75 acres. The total assessed value of the site is $200,333.

Rich Giraulo, a civil engineer with LandTech Surveying and Planning in Greece, said developers intend to purchase an adjacent parcel and would need both rezoned before the project could move forward. And, he said, looking at potential ways to ease traffic at the sometimes problematic and busy intersection of Latta and North Greece roads would also be part of the project.

He said the location of the existing building exacerbates those issues, as it leaves no room to expand the intersection. "If this does move forward, we will have the opportunity to have more space there."
The meeting, which is intended for neighbors of the project, will be held at 7 p.m. at the North Greece Firemen's Field, 3666 Latta Road.
MCDERMOT@Gannett.com
►Greece hotel had many names — and saw many eras

articleBody.value: Richard Leon Wilbern, accused in the 2003 Xerox Federal Credit Union robbery and homicide, was indicted by a federal grand jury Tuesday, the U.S. Attorney's Office announced.
Wilbern, 56, was charged in two separate indictments. Wilbern is accused of robbing the Xerox Federal Credit Union in August 2003 and fatally shooting Raymond Batzel during the robbery.
Wilbern is charged with armed robbery which resulted in the death of Batzel on Aug. 12, 2003. The charge carries a maximum sentence of life in prison.
The second indictment charged Wilbern with unlawful possession of a firearm by a previously felon convicted. That carries a maximum of 10 years in prison.
File Video: FBI releases details of Xerox Federal Credit Union robbery/homicide.

Wilbern allegedly entered the Xerox Federal Credit Union in Webster on Aug. 12, 2003, carrying a large brief case and an umbrella. Authorities allege he was wearing an "FBI raid jacket, sunglasses, a U.S. Marshals badge and a wig."
He left behind the umbrella, which "was subsequently tested and discovered to contain his DNA."

Wilbern, who has two previous felony convictions, was charged 13 years later in the Xerox shooting. On Sept. 27, 2016, Wilbern was taken into custody. Prosecutors said he had four firearms at his girlfriend's home on Tubman Way in Rochester.
Federal authorities said those weapons included:

• one Feather Industries Inc. Model AT-9, 9 mm rifle firearm loaded with 25 rounds in the magazine
  • one Norinco SKS rifle loaded with 11 rounds of 7.62 x 39 caliber ammunition
  • one SAA Model SA15 semi-automatic rifle, along with two empty magazine clips
  • one Kel Tec model Sub-2000, .40 Smith and Wesson caliber rifle.
Wilbern, who is currently being held without bail pending a detention hearing, will be arraigned at 9:30 a.m. Friday before U.S. Magistrate Judge Jonathan W. Feldman.
WCLEVELAND@Gannett.com

articleBody.value: A Rochester man was sentenced Tuesday for the second time for a 2001 murder.

Jose Torres, 48, was originally convicted of the murder of Miguel Danny Cruz in 2002. That conviction was overturned last year after an imprisoned murderer, Angel Carasquillo, confessed to the Cruz killing.
State Supreme Court Justice Francis Affronti sentenced Torres, who was convicted for the second time last month, to 25 years to life in prison.
According to the Monroe County District Attorney's Office, a grand jury indicted Carrasquillo as an accomplice in the Cruz murder last year. Carrasquillo's trial is expected to begin later this year.
After the original conviction was overturned, the District Attorney's Office then pursued the crime under a new theory — that Torres and Carasquillo acted together.
Carasquillo, serving a life sentence for another murder, is now set to be tried separately for the Cruz killing.
Affronti overturned the earlier conviction after a hearing at which Carasquillo testified and another man also provided evidence pointing to Carasquillo as the killer.
► Judge reverses 2002 murder conviction of Jose Torres

Prosecutors then chose to seek an indictment of Carasquillo and to try the two of them for the homicide. Prosecutors said evidence shows that Torres confessed to the Cruz killing within hours of the murder.

Torres also confessed to the Rochester Police Department the following day, prosecutors said. In his confession, Torres gave details about the killing, "such as that he used a .38-caliber gun and that he fired four bullets," a release said.
► Witnesses: Torres convicted of murder he didn't commit

He also led police to the spot in the Genesee River where he threw the weapon into the water. Police recovered .38-caliber bullets at that spot in the river. Torres' confession lined up with evidence gathered at the crime scene and witness testimony.
“Jose Torres executed Miguel Danny Cruz on July 4, 2001, as he innocently enjoyed the holiday with family and friends,” Assistant District Attorney Michael Bezer said in a release.
WCLEVELAND@Gannett.com

content.author: Will Cleveland, @WillCleveland13

articleBody.value: Jalen Everett was acquitted Wednesday of the triple homicide on Genesee Street — the second time he has been tried for the crimes.
Everett's earlier second-degree murder conviction in the 2015 Genesee Street killings was tossed out by County Court Judge Douglas Randall after allegations of juror misconduct.
The jury took little time Wednesday finding him not guilty. It began deliberations in the morning and reached a verdict before 2 p.m.

A jury in November convicted Everett of second-degree murder, deciding he was involved in the 2015 drive-by shooting that left three dead in the Boys & Girls Club parking lot. However, after the verdict, a juror claimed that another juror had made racial comments and, during the trial, discussed information that the jury had not been allowed to hear.
Randall decided the claims of the juror were credible, and overturned the guilty verdict in December.

Everett was one of three men accused of the triple homicide outside the Boys & Girls Club, 500 Genesee St., on Aug. 19, 2015. One of the accused, Johnny Blackshell Jr., has been convicted of murder and sentenced to life in prison, while the other defendant, Michael Mathis, 19, will be tried separately.
Three young men — Jonah Barley, Raekwon Manigault and Johnny Johnson — died in the shooting. Three more were injured.
GCRAIG@Gannett.com

content.author: Sean Lahman, and Gary Craig, Democrat and Chronicle

articleBody.value: The waiting is finally over.
Dow 20,000 – a milestone that seemed out of reach and had a science-fiction feel to it at the 2009 market low when the iconic stock index traded at 6,547, 54% below its then-peak – is now a reality.

In a historic moment on Wall Street, the Dow Jones industrial average eclipsed the milestone Wednesday for the first time in its 120-year history. The Dow jumped nearly 170 points in afternoon trading to hit an intraday record high of 20,082.00.

It took the Dow, a stock gauge made up of 30 of America’s best-known blue-chip companies, just 64 calendar days to climb from 19,000 to 20,000, its second-fastest thousand-point sprint, according to S&P Dow Jones Indices. The climb from 10,000 to 11,000 back in 1999 took just 35 days.
"It's a nice mile marker," says Chris Zaccarelli, chief investment officer at Cornerstone Financial Partners.

The run to Dow 20,000 punctuates a massive 205% move from its bear market low in March 2009, marked by a final dash of nearly 1,700 points, or more than 9%, since Election Day when Donald Trump’s surprise win and business-friendly policy proposals set in motion a rise in stock prices.

The Dow's final punch above 20,000 comes just four trading days into Trump's presidency, a whirlwind in which the billionaire has reaffirmed his commitment to strengthen the U.S. economy and create more jobs and higher wages for workers via his "America First" economic policies.

The Dow’s rewriting of the record books also kicks off a debate as to whether the new record marks the start of a new up leg for the nearly 8-year-old bull market, or whether it will mark an eventual market top like Dow 10,000 did back in 1999 and usher in another long money-losing period for stock investors.

To say anyone saw Dow 20,000 coming in early 2009 at the bottom of the worst market meltdown since the Great Depression would probably be telling a fib. On March 9, 2009, the day the Dow troughed, pessimism dominated. Chatter about Dow 5,000 – not Dow 20,000 or even Dow 10,000 -- was making the rounds. “Dow 5,000? There’s a Case for It,” a Wall Street Journal headline declared.

The pessimists were wrong. The Dow, thanks to bailouts of banks, automakers and other companies engineered by the Obama administration, and unprecedented stimulus from the U.S. Federal Reserve that enabled the economy to heal and U.S. companies to start making money again, was able to mount a comeback few Wall Street pros saw coming or thought possible.

Bulls are now betting on a better economy under president Trump and a shift in the key market driver from Fed-driven stimulus such as low interest rates to fiscal spending by the federal government to push stock prices higher.

“Our market indicators are pointing to a healthy advance and we recommend investing like this is a healthy advance,” Ari Wald, a stock market analyst at money-management firm Oppenheimer, said in the run-up to the milestone. “Should Dow 20,000 bring sellers in, we expect it to be short-lived and to be followed by higher highs.”

Given that the Dow’s latest surge has been driven mainly by hopes that Trump’s plans to lower corporate taxes, reduce regulations on businesses and spend billions on infrastructure will be enacted and juice the economy, some Wall Street pros are urging caution, given that the stock market is no longer cheap.

“It can be very dangerous to get too caught up in the market’s euphoria about as-yet unfulfilled campaign promises,” says Michael Farr, president of money management firm Farr, Miller & Washington. The Dow's surge the past two sessions has been partly driven by Trump's quick start in moving his agenda forward, but many details remain scant, Farr adds. "The trend is up for now, but know it won't last forever."
What's more, market gains often stall near big, round numbers like Dow 20,000.

"Typically, major milestones have acted as ceilings, and for an index to break through convincingly takes a lot of energy," says Brad McMillan, chief investment officer at Commonwealth Financial Network.

content.shortHeadline: Finally! Dow makes history, cracks 20,000 barrier
content.about: The waiting is finally over.Dow 20,000 – a milestone that seemed out of reach and had a science-fiction feel to it at the 2009 market low when the iconic stock index traded at 6,547, 54% below its then-peak – is now a reality.In a historic moment on Wall Street, the Dow Jones industrial average eclipsed the milestone Wednesday for the first time in its 120-year history. The Dow jumped nearly 170 points in afternoon trading to hit an intraday record high of 20,082.00.It took the Dow, a stock gauge made up of 30 of America’s best-known blue-chip companies, just 64 calendar days to climb from 19,000 to 20,000, its second-fastest thousand-point sprint, according to S&P Dow Jones Indices. The climb from 10,000 to 11,000 back in 1999 took just 35 days.

articleBody.value: ALBANY -- Three seconds is about all it took to bring an 85-year-old bridge to its demise.

State officials were in the town of Marbletown in Ulster County on Wednesday to implode a 275-foot bridge crossing the Roundout Creek on Route 213, clearing the way for a new $12.4 million span that will include a pedestrian walkway.
Gov. Andrew Cuomo was among the officials who pressed the button to launch the implosion.
He spared few words as he opened his pre-implosion remarks.
“So, we’re here to blow up a bridge," Cuomo said to laughs.
Cuomo said the new bridge will be a "better" and "safer" bridge with better views.
"Life is tough when you’re a bridge," he said.

"You work for 85 years, stand up through storms, rain, carry vehicles every day. Then at retirement, you don’t get a watch, you don’t get a pension, you don’t get a thank you. All they do is blow you up.”
Cuomo said the event marked the halfway point of the state's $542 million Empire Bridge program to replace 100 aging bridges across the state.

articleBody.value: Be it curling his reddish mustache into a handlebar look, talking to reporters and teammates about movies and rock climbing, or describing his variety of colorful masks, Rochester Americans goaltender Linus Ullmark isn’t it any danger of developing an ulcer playing hockey’s most stressful position.
American food will take down the Swedish sensation before pressure will. Ullmark, 23, is a guy whose easygoing demeanor serves him well both on and off the ice.

“I try to have a good mindset and go out there and have fun,’’ said the Amerks ironman netminder Tuesday before a key three-game week followed by the AHL’s All-Star break which Ullmark has been selected to take part in. “I feel I’m not having fun when I start to struggle and it shows pretty fast when I’m mad or angry. So I try to be easygoing, it drives my fiancé a little nuts — too easygoing — but that’s life. Hakuna Matata.’’
Popularized by the 1994 movie The Lion King, Hakuna Matata is Swahili for “no worries,’’ which pretty much sums up how the Amerks feel when Ullmark is between the pipes.

You wouldn’t think an All-Star goaltender would come from a sub-.500 team in last place in its division. But Ullmark’s invitation is in recognition of just how well he has played, the workload he has carried and a realization of how much worse it could be for his team if not for his stellar play.

Ullmark (16-14-1 record) leads AHL goaltenders in shots (980), saves (892), games played (31) and minutes (1,805). He and left wing Cole Schneider, the Amerks leading scorer with 38 points, will represent Rochester in the AHL All-Star Classic on Sunday and Monday at the PPL Center in Allentown, Pennsylvania.

“I was surprised, you never think you’re an all-star, you just go out and play for your team, play for the boys, and you just want to do your best,’’ Ullmark said. “I’m happy that the AHL wants me to be there, but I have to thank everyone that helped me get there.’’
That would include center Peter Forsberg and goalie Dominik Hasek, two legendary NHL players for Colorado and Buffalo among other teams who inspired a young boy growing up in Lugnvik, Sweden.

More recently, Ullmark could thank Amerks coach Dan Lambert, who has called his number most nights this season, allowing his talent to flourish under the workload. But as a rookie coach of a young squad, it’s Lambert who is thanking Ullmark for making his mark.

“Linus is an all-star for a reason,’’ said Lambert, whose 18-23-0-1 team plays home Wednesday against Toronto and Friday against Albany. “He’s been very consistent for us … And when you have a young team like we do it’s important to be able to make some mistakes and he’s there to bail you out. That’s the importance of a good goalie and I think in Linus’ development as well. He understands he can be a difference maker.’’

Ullmark has averaged nearly 30 saves over his last dozen games (8-4-0) and 40-save nights have not been uncommon. Last season as a rookie, he had a 51-save performance in a 6-2 win over Syracuse, which was the most saves by an Amerks goalie in six years.
As strange as it sounds, being a target in a shooting gallery is fun. It’s a goalie thing.

“It’s fun but it depends on how the game is,’’ Ullmark said. “If there are a lot of rebound shots, it’s hard but as long as we keep shots from the outside, from the boards, if I have a clear view it’s not that hard from a physical side. You just have to be able to withstand all the shots and be fully focused.’’
The 6-foot-4, 212-pound Ullmark is part of a Swedish Invasion of big goaltenders in the Buffalo Sabres system. Countrymen Robin Lehner, 25, and Anders Nilsson, 26, are sharing the work in Buffalo.
Ullmark met Nilsson for the first time as members of Team Sweden that won a bronze medal at the 2014 World Championships in Belarus; Nilsson was the starter going 6-2 with a 1.54 GAA.

“I knew he was a very good goalie and I found out he was also a very good person,’’ Ullmark said. “That’s what you want to be on and off the ice. You don’t want to be a diva or a guy who thinks he’s a big shot.’’
Because of the humbling nature of the job, that’s usually not a problem for goalies.

Ullmark, a sixth-round 2012 Sabres draft pick, came up through the ranks with Sweden’s famed MODO hockey club, whose NHL alumni include Forsberg, Anders Hedberg, Markus Naslund, Niklas Sundstrom and the Sedin brothers.
A wide-eyed teammate of many veteran pros, Ullmark was 2013-14 Goaltender of the Year in the pro Swedish Hockey League and made the jump to North America last season.

In addition to playing 28 games for the Amerks, he appeared in 20 games for the Sabres when Lehner suffered a bad ankle injury, posting an encouraging 8-10-2 record with 2.60 goals-against average and .913 save percentage.
Knowing that goaltender development is a slow ride on a roller-coaster, Ullmark was elated for logging some NHL playing time so soon.

“You can’t even look at last year, I wasn’t even supposed to be there,’’ he said. “I want to be there, of course, but it’s not my time yet. They have two very good goalies with the Sabres who put on a show every night. For me, I have to prove myself here every night.’’
He’s doing that with a winning combination of size, skill and the right attitude.

“The first thing you notice about Linus is his size, he’s a big guy and there’s not much to shoot at,’’ veteran forward Tim Kennedy said. “What also helps him is that he’s very calm and has a patient demeanor. He just doesn’t get rattled.’’
Or apparently, tired.

Backups John Muse and Jason Kasdorf have appeared in only 13 games combined because of Ullmark’s stamina and consistency. He said adjusting his diet to what he is used to eating in Sweden — a lot of fish — has been important. And OK, the occasional Swedish meatball.

“It’s a different type of schedule coming from Europe playing 55 games at tops and here in the AHL where it’s 76 games and you play every weekend,’’ he said. “There are no real days off. It was hard to adjust to, to keep my body in shape, so that is something I’m taking care of a lot better this year.’’

Ullmark’s array of masks painted with the Minions movie google eyes or Bowser from Super Mario Bros., one of his favorite video games, are a hit with fans. He plans to display his goalie masks in the man cave of the first house he purchases, after he lands a full-time NHL address.

“A coach once said, ‘If you’re good enough, you are going to get there,’ " Ullmark said.  “That’s what I’ve tried to believe in. If I’m good enough I’ll get the chance. If not then I need to work harder. That’s why I don’t get so stressed about my development. If they feel like I’m not ready or something, then I just have to keep working more.’’
Hakuna Matata.’’
